content.description:
Scuz Ball

,

Squeeze-n-Tease

,

L.D. Getaway

, and

Andy Devine

are located (in that order, from left to right) on an unnamed cliff a couple hundred feet uphill and west of the main Little Wing formation. All of these routes are of mediocre quality, usually featuring some good climbing mixed with some not-so-good climbing. If you want a cliff with sunny moderates and zero crowds, this isn't a bad choice. There are rap slings on a tree above

Andy Devine

, which is the easiest way to descend.

------------------

Some 3rd class scrambling is required to reach the slabby ledge below this route. Start up the low angle corner with a hand crack to reach the steeper headwall. The fist crack above is blocked by a flake protruding from the right. Getting around this is the crux. Be gentle with the flake. From here it's a 5.6 offwidth to the top. It is also possible to escape right if you don't have a big cam to protect the offwidth.

Scuz Ball

,

Squeeze-n-Tease

,

L.D. Getaway

, and

Andy Devine

are located (in that order, from left to right) on an unnamed cliff a couple hundred feet uphill and west of the main Little Wing formation. All of these routes are of mediocre quality, usually featuring some good climbing mixed with some not-so-good climbing. If you want a cliff with sunny moderates and zero crowds, this isn't a bad choice. There are rap slings on a tree above

Andy Devine

, which is the easiest way to descend.

------------------

Near the left end of the formation is a left-facing corner. Begin up a blocky chimney, climb up the dihedral and finish with a fun layback (crux) up a clean fist crack.

climbs.name: The Riddler
climbs.fa: Bruce Pollock, Matt Pollock, Mark Chapman, and Charlie Porter (Jan '74)

content.description:
The line of the Riddler can't be missed from the base of Little Wing: a wild, curled flake bends and overlaps the cliff face, creating a striking flared chimney that rises 80 ft to top out on a flat ledge.  Gain this intimidating feature after 15 ft of steep and protected face climbing to find good protection and sound jams in the back of the chimney.  Fight your way up to a bolted anchor with rap rings on top.

This climb can either be a grunter or a silky smooth ascent, depending on your technique.  Either way, it's an excellent and safe opportunity to gain experience with that classic Yosemite genre: the chimney/squeeze.
content.protection: Small to 3".  In spite of its wide aspect, this climb protects very well.
content.location: Traverse right along the base of Little Wing cliff; eventually you'll emerge onto a small, semi-exposed platform at the far right (east) end of the cliff.  Honor Thy Father, Leisure Time, The Riddler, and Little Wing all begin from this platform.  The Riddler starts up steep, bouldery moves and enters the obvious chimney feature.

climbs.name: Little Wing
climbs.fa: Mark Chapman, Charlie Porter, and Bruce Pollock - January 1974

content.description: This is a great thin line. The crux is down low Passing a rooflet and a small left facing section. You are on your tips here and the feet are small and slick. Continue up and to the left. Some parties rappel from slings around a block and/or horn, and some traverse over to the anchor bolts on top of the Riddler/Leisure Time to rap. An excellent pitch well worth the time to hike there.
content.protection: Bring the small half of your rack and double it. Slings may be useful.
content.location: Right side of the cliff next to a bay tree.

climbs.name: Leisure Time
climbs.fa: George Meyers, Bob Ashworth, and Mike Breidenbach (Apr '74)

content.description: This route follows a series of cracks and flakes up the center of the Little Wing crag, in between Honor Thy Father and The Riddler. The pitch is characterized by steep climbing on juggy holds, good jams, and plenty of rest spots - more typical of the climbing at Lover's Leap than the Valley. The climb finishes through a couple flared bulges to reach the left side of the ledge The Riddler also finishes on.

Scuz Ball

,

Squeeze-n-Tease

,

L.D. Getaway

, and

Andy Devine

are located (in that order, from left to right) on an unnamed cliff a couple hundred feet uphill and west of the main Little Wing formation. All of these routes are of mediocre quality, usually featuring some good climbing mixed with some not-so-good climbing. If you want a cliff with sunny moderates and zero crowds, this isn't a bad choice. There are rap slings on a tree above

Andy Devine

, which is the easiest way to descend.

------------------

Near the center of the formation is an obvious splitter up a headwall. Below this is a large slab/ledge. Start to the right up a short crack to gain the ledge. Continue up the slab to the left to reach the base of a perfect handcrack. This section is really fun; if it went on 5 times longer this route would be a classic. Steep hand jams leads to easier climbing up a corner.

This crack is pretty in your face off the ground, but you can sew it up. The crack follows a ramp with interesting water pockets. It is quite polished in some places. I found the crux to be the bottom third of the route, liebacking and then pulling into a stance. The roof at the top looks hard from the ground, but it no harder than 5.9 and takes bomber pro.
content.protection:
Doubles up to #2 Camalot and one #3 (for the roof) will get you up. Take a good selection of nuts as there are a lot spots to use them.

Also, as of 4/5/09 the belay slings were way tattered. I ended up building a natural anchor and walking off (not recommended).
content.location:
Route is just left of Leisure Time.

At the top you have a few options

-Rap off some slings on a horn near the top of the pitch.

-Scramble and downclimb (5th class) to the bolt anchors on the ledge shared by The Riddler and Leisure Time.

-Head towards the top of the formation and then scramble down and left(west) through vegetation and a 3rd class gully to reach the talus field adjacent to the wall.

climbs.name: He Can't Shout, Don't Hear You

content.description:
This route climbs a corner system on the left side of the cliff.

This is probably the hardest 5.7 that I have ever done.

Scuz Ball

,

Squeeze-n-Tease

,

L.D. Getaway

, and

Andy Devine

are located (in that order, from left to right) on an unnamed cliff a couple hundred feet uphill and west of the main Little Wing formation. All of these routes are of mediocre quality, usually featuring some good climbing mixed with some not-so-good climbing. If you want a cliff with sunny moderates and zero crowds, this isn't a bad choice. There are rap slings on a tree above

Andy Devine

, which is the easiest way to descend.

------------------

Located in a right-facing corner at the right end of the cliff. Begin up a runout slab/ramp to the right to avoid the roof. A direct start is also possible on top rope, starting off a boulder, and goes at about 5.10- (somewhat height dependent). Continue up the easy corner using caution to avoid the loose rock near the top.
